Description: A hollow terracotta model of a metal Isis-situla: bell-shaped with a moulded rim and a swing loop handle with a pierced suspension ring. Coiled within is a cobra, wearing a sun-disc. Back plain, with a small circular vent. The knob at the bottom of the vessel is lost. Two-piece mould. Orange-brown Nile silt, with a brown surface; no apparent mica. Traces of a white dressing overall, thicker on the front than the back.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired in the Fayum. Probably Roman, first or second century AD. Comparanda. Close, probably same mould-series: Dunand 1990: no. 975, dated Roman period. For an actual Isis-situla in bronze, with a similar swing handle, see Bénazeth 1992: 50.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3279)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
